<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SCIENCE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/24/undefined?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
How to turn your kid into a boss baby
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/24/undefined?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt="Still from the movie Boss Baby " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/b9946e5c2df417886913c23ee4844ce05b141656-448x252.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>DreamWorks</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Money. Highly anticipated research published yesterday in the <em>Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences</em> showed that <a href="https://www.vox.com/future-perfect/22893313/cash-babies-brain-development?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">direct payments</a> to low-income families appear to significantly affect the brain development of newborns.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How the experiment worked: </strong>Researchers recruited hundreds of low-income mothers of newborns and separated them into two groups:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>One group of mothers received $20 a month, and the other received $333. Do some quick back-of-the-napkin math, and you'll find the difference in income was $3,756 annually.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Over the study period (which is ongoing until the kids reach at least four years old), the researchers measured the infants’ brain waves by strapping them into a baby-friendly, brain-scanning cap.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What they found one year in: </strong>Babies whose mothers received $333/month showed a greater prevalence of higher-frequency brain activity than the $20/month cohort. That brain activity is often, but not always, associated with better cognitive skills down the line.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The researchers say this is a game changer: “This is the first study to show that money, in and of itself, has a causal impact on brain development,” study co-author and Columbia University neuroscientist Dr. Kimberly G. Noble <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/01/24/us/politics/child-tax-credit-brain-function.html?referringSource=articleShare" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">told the NYT</a>.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Coming to a C-SPAN broadcast near you</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">This study is not the kind that will be buried in the back of a dusty academic journal—it could have an immediate effect on policy debates on Capitol Hill.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">It’s all about the child tax credit.</strong> Under an expanded child tax credit program, the Biden administration had been sending up to $300 per child to US households. In December, the program had reduced monthly child poverty by <a href="https://finance.yahoo.com/news/child-tax-credit-child-poverty-140640669.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">nearly 30%</a>, according to an analysis by the Columbia University’s Center on Poverty and Social Policy.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But that credit expired at the end of 2021. Biden and progressive Democrats wanted to extend the program through the Build Back Better Act, but…we all know what happened to that bill.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>While debates around the child tax credit have mostly focused on incentives for <em>parents</em>, this research highlights the effect of cash transfers for children, throwing a new variable into the conversation.—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
DATA PRIVACY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/google-sued-deceptive-tracking?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
For Google, it's all about location, location, location
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/google-sued-deceptive-tracking?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="A Google location pin going in and out of focus." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=447 src="https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2022-01-24/image-a95336a2dfc190721c8b0e4f27f5a37dcf6fd3c8-1500x1000-gif/google-maps-012422-01.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="A Google location pin going in and out of focus." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2022-01-24/image-a95336a2dfc190721c8b0e4f27f5a37dcf6fd3c8-1500x1000-gif/google-maps-012422-01.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Illustration: Dianna “Mick” McDougall; Sources: Getty Images, Google</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Google's ongoing corporate mission to dominate the National Geography Bee finally has some states fed up. Texas, Indiana, Washington state, and Washington, DC, sued Google on Monday, alleging in separate lawsuits that—from at least 2014 to 2019—the <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/01/24/technology/google-location-services-lawsuit.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">company deceived users</a> about when it was tracking their location.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The lawsuits allege that although users were able to “turn off” their location history, Google continued tracking their movements through other means and employed several tactics to pressure consumers into granting the company more access. “In reality, consumers who use Google products cannot prevent Google from collecting, storing, and profiting from their location," DC’s complaint reads.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>How does it profit? Google employs its users’ location data to build out more robust profiles it can use to lure advertisers. The information also allows advertisers to see how effective their campaigns are at driving foot traffic.</span></li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The lawsuits came out of a three-year investigation following <a href="https://apnews.com/article/north-america-science-technology-business-ap-top-news-828aefab64d4411bac257a07c1af0ecb?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reporting by the Associated Press</a> that showed Google stores user location data despite privacy settings. The cases seek to stop Google from collecting location data from users who’ve attempted to opt out, and impose a fine on the company.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Google, in response, said that the lawsuits are “based on inaccurate claims and outdated assertions about our settings.”—<em>MK</em></p>
</div>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
EDUCATION
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/supreme-court-affirmative-action?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
Affirmative action heads to the Supreme Court
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/supreme-court-affirmative-action?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt="US Supreme Court" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/c73c43b9218ca451f4811c5cdc14a8aa712c7ca1-7360x4912.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Matt Anderson/Getty Images</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The current Supreme Court is giving your uncle a run for his money when it comes to discussing controversial topics. In addition to hearing cases on abortion, gun regulations, and vaccine mandates, the court <a href="https://apnews.com/article/college-admissions-race-and-ethnicity-racial-injustice-religion-affirmative-action-5fd79b529db78daee370de22ae17909f?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">added</a> affirmative action to its docket yesterday. SCOTUS will hear two cases that could shake up the admissions process at public and private colleges and universities across the US.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Students for Fair Admissions, a group led by anti-affirmative action crusader <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/19/us/affirmative-action-lawsuits.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Edward Blum</a>, who’s no stranger to the high court, sued Harvard University and the University of North Carolina for discriminating against Asian American applicants. In the Harvard case, the group argues that the school gave “massive preferences” to Black and Hispanic students.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Harvard has denied the claims and lower courts have sided with Harvard in previous cases.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Harvard’s current freshman class makeup is 52% white, 24% Asian, 11% Black, and 10% Hispanic. The school said that if it got rid of its current race-conscious admissions, “African-American and Hispanic representation would decline by nearly half.” </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out:</strong> Historically, conservative justices have voted against race-conscious admission programs but were usually outnumbered—now, they have a sizable majority at 6–3. Arguments will likely begin in the fall.<em>—MM</em></p>
</div>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GRAB BAG
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/24/key-performance-indicators-january-25?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
Key performance indicators
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/24/key-performance-indicators-january-25?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt="Telsla Fremont plant" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/1fc0e26c17ff32cccc7a5f3246d374e4df022304-1200x793.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Tesla</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>Tesla’s plant in Fremont, CA, is the <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/graphics/2022-tesla-factory-california-texas-car-production/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">most productive</a> auto factory in North America, according to a Bloomberg analysis. Cranking out 8,550 cars a week, Elon’s manufacturing facility beat out more than 70 others from legacy carmakers such as Toyota, BMW, and Ford.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>“What a stupid son of a b****.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">President Biden will have to wash his mouth out with soap after <a href="https://www.axios.com/biden-reporter-blast-inflation-d3b832f1-6170-4f31-a34c-8229f1cb9ec5.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">tearing into</a> Fox News White House correspondent Peter Doocy yesterday. Doocy had asked Biden whether inflation would be a political liability for the midterms, which apparently the president did not appreciate.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Read: </strong>Bill McCamley was NM’s labor secretary, but working at a local movie theater taught him the truth about what’s ailing the workforce. (<a href="https://jasonstanford.substack.com/p/he-thought-tending-bar-sounded-like?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">The Experiment</a>)</p>
</div>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
HEALTH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/mark-cuban-online-pharmacy-generic-drugs?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
Mark Cuban's selling generic drugs online
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>

<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/mark-cuban-online-pharmacy-generic-drugs?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Mark Cuban trying on a face mask." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=377 src="https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2022-01-24/image-d99a1d1a8e2020be48c30a44c209affd97c03a64-480x270-gif/giphy.gif">

<img class="story-header-image" alt="Mark Cuban trying on a face mask." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2022-01-24/image-d99a1d1a8e2020be48c30a44c209affd97c03a64-480x270-gif/giphy.gif">

</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>ABC</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em>Shark Tank</em>, basketball, and generic drugs: a great sick day plan and also the three things Mark Cuban is now known for. The billionaire owner of the Dallas Mavericks has launched an online pharmacy for generic drugs that looks to cut out middlemen and combat pharmaceutical industry price gouging by offering steep discounts.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Mark Cuban Cost Plus Drug Company set up <a href="https://costplusdrugs.com/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">CostPlusDrugs.com</a> last week with 100 generic drugs to treat conditions like diabetes and asthma. Cost Plus will not accept health insurance but claims its prices will still be lower than what people would typically pay at a pharmacy. “All drugs are priced at cost plus 15%!” Cuban tweeted Thursday.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>One example: A month’s supply of Imatinib, a drug used to treat leukemia, retails for around $9,600, and $120 per month with a voucher. Cost Plus’s price: $47 a month.</span></li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The company is building an $11 million drug manufacturing plant in the Dallas area that it hopes to complete by April. Cuban tweeted that the plant will allow the company to expand into injectables.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>A September Gallup poll found that 18 million Americans were not able to afford at least one prescribed medication in the previous three months.—<em>MK</em></p>
</div>

color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nHow to turn your kid into a boss baby \n\u003c/font\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ca style=\"text-decoration:none;border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/24/undefined?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Still from the movie Boss Baby \" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/b9946e5c2df417886913c23ee4844ce05b141656-448x252.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan class=\"source\" style=\"display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eDreamWorks\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eMoney. Highly anticipated research published yesterday in the \u003cem\u003eProceedings of the National Academy of Sciences\u003c/em\u003e showed that \u003ca href=\"https://www.vox.com/future-perfect/22893313/cash-babies-brain-development?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edirect payments\u003c/a\u003e to low-income families appear to significantly affect the brain development of newborns.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow the experiment worked: \u003c/strong\u003eResearchers recruited hundreds of low-income mothers of newborns and separated them into two groups:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOne group of mothers received $20 a month, and the other received $333. Do some quick back-of-the-napkin math, and you'll find the difference in income was $3,756 annually.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOver the study period (which is ongoing until the kids reach at least four years old), the researchers measured the infants’ brain waves by strapping them into a baby-friendly, brain-scanning cap.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat they found one year in: \u003c/strong\u003eBabies whose mothers received $333/month showed a greater prevalence of higher-frequency brain activity than the $20/month cohort. That brain activity is often, but not always, associated with better cognitive skills down the line.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe researchers say this is a game changer: “This is the first study to show that money, in and of itself, has a causal impact on brain development,” study co-author and Columbia University neuroscientist Dr. Kimberly G. Noble \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/01/24/us/politics/child-tax-credit-brain-function.html?referringSource=articleShare\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etold the NYT\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eComing to a C-SPAN broadcast near you\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThis study is not the kind that will be buried in the back of a dusty academic journal—it could have an immediate effect on policy debates on Capitol Hill.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eIt’s all about the child tax credit.\u003c/strong\u003e Under an expanded child tax credit program, the Biden administration had been sending up to $300 per child to US households. In December, the program had reduced monthly child poverty by \u003ca href=\"https://finance.yahoo.com/news/child-tax-credit-child-poverty-140640669.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enearly 30%\u003c/a\u003e, according to an analysis by the Columbia University’s Center on Poverty and Social Policy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut that credit expired at the end of 2021. Biden and progressive Democrats wanted to extend the program through the Build Back Better Act, but…we all know what happened to that bill.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eWhile debates around the child tax credit have mostly focused on incentives for \u003cem\u003eparents\u003c/em\u003e, this research highlights the effect of cash transfers for children, throwing a new variable into the conversation.—\u003cem\u003eNF\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" class=\"source\" style=\"display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eIllustration: Dianna “Mick” McDougall; Sources: Getty Images, Google\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eGoogle's ongoing corporate mission to dominate the National Geography Bee finally has some states fed up. Texas, Indiana, Washington state, and Washington, DC, sued Google on Monday, alleging in separate lawsuits that—from at least 2014 to 2019—the \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2022/01/24/technology/google-location-services-lawsuit.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecompany deceived users\u003c/a\u003e about when it was tracking their location.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe lawsuits allege that although users were able to “turn off” their location history, Google continued tracking their movements through other means and employed several tactics to pressure consumers into granting the company more access. “In reality, consumers who use Google products cannot prevent Google from collecting, storing, and profiting from their location,\" DC’s complaint reads.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHow does it profit? Google employs its users’ location data to build out more robust profiles it can use to lure advertisers. The information also allows advertisers to see how effective their campaigns are at driving foot traffic.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe lawsuits came out of a three-year investigation following \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/north-america-science-technology-business-ap-top-news-828aefab64d4411bac257a07c1af0ecb?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereporting by the Associated Press\u003c/a\u003e that showed Google stores user location data despite privacy settings. The cases seek to stop Google from collecting location data from users who’ve attempted to opt out, and impose a fine on the company.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eGoogle, in response, said that the lawsuits are “based on inaccurate claims and outdated assertions about our settings.”—\u003cem\u003eMK\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nAffirmative action heads to the Supreme Court\n\u003c/font\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ca src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/c73c43b9218ca451f4811c5cdc14a8aa712c7ca1-7360x4912.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan class=\"source\" style=\"display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eMatt Anderson/Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe current Supreme Court is giving your uncle a run for his money when it comes to discussing controversial topics. In addition to hearing cases on abortion, gun regulations, and vaccine mandates, the court \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/college-admissions-race-and-ethnicity-racial-injustice-religion-affirmative-action-5fd79b529db78daee370de22ae17909f?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eadded\u003c/a\u003e affirmative action to its docket yesterday. SCOTUS will hear two cases that could shake up the admissions process at public and private colleges and universities across the US.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eStudents for Fair Admissions, a group led by anti-affirmative action crusader \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/19/us/affirmative-action-lawsuits.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eEdward Blum\u003c/a\u003e, who’s no stranger to the high court, sued Harvard University and the University of North Carolina for discriminating against Asian American applicants. In the Harvard case, the group argues that the school gave “massive preferences” to Black and Hispanic students.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHarvard has denied the claims and lower courts have sided with Harvard in previous cases.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHarvard’s current freshman class makeup is 52% white, 24% Asian, 11% Black, and 10% Hispanic. The school said that if it got rid of its current race-conscious admissions, “African-American and Hispanic representation would decline by nearly half.” \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out:\u003c/strong\u003e Historically, conservative justices have voted against race-conscious admission programs but were usually outnumbered—now, they have a sizable majority at 6–3. Arguments will likely begin in the fall.\u003cem\u003e—MM\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eShark Tank\u003c/em\u003e, basketball, and generic drugs: a great sick day plan and also the three things Mark Cuban is The billionaire owner of the Dallas Mavericks has launched an online pharmacy for generic drugs that looks to cut out middlemen and combat pharmaceutical industry price gouging by offering steep discounts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Mark Cuban Cost Plus Drug Company set up \u003ca href=\"https://costplusdrugs.com/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eCostPlusDrugs.com\u003c/a\u003e last week with 100 generic drugs to treat conditions like diabetes and asthma. Cost Plus will not accept health insurance but claims its prices will still be lower than what people would typically pay at a pharmacy. “All drugs are priced at cost plus 15%!” Cuban tweeted Thursday.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOne example: A month’s supply of Imatinib, a drug used to treat leukemia, retails for around $9,600, and $120 per month with a voucher.
